intro: Didymoglossum ballardianum, commonly known as the Ballardian moss, is a small, cushion-forming liverwort belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its dense, mat-like growth and is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as rock crevices or forest floors. The plant has a prostrate growth habit with closely appressed leaves that are often covered in a layer of fine, translucent cells. It is primarily distributed in temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, including parts of North America and Asia. Due to its limited range and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and often overlooked member of the liverwort flora.
